responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Single-versioned software with supplementary delivery and maintenance services, faster consumption of innovation, elimination of version management complexity
Customer Segment: Small and medium enterprises (most aggressive adopters), large corporations, diverse industries with varied usage patterns
Revenue Streams: Recurring subscription fees (pay-as-you-go), usage fees, service fees (helpdesk, backup, security, setup/training, configuration/integration)
Key Resources: Single-versioned multi-tenant software architecture, hosting infrastructure
Key Activities: Hosting and maintaining software, provision of supplementary services (backup, security), functionality enhancements and service innovations
Cost Structure: Hosting and maintenance costs, provision of supplementary services, significant variable costs from remote hosting
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'By hosting single-versioned software coupled with supplementary delivery and maintenance services, SaaS vendors can effectively differentiate their product offerings from that of traditional on-premise software (TOPS)' | Page 1: 'For clients, the consumption of innovation is faster as new capabilities are released simultaneously with each service upgrade. For vendors, the complexities and costs associated with managing and maintaining multiple software versions can be eliminated, thereby freeing up resources to focus on functionality enhancements and service innovations' | Page 2: 'The second challenge comes from the diversity of SaaS clients, among which small and medium enterprises have been the most aggressive adopters. Likewise, large corporations are equally attracted to the idea of acquiring software services on demand' | Page 1-2: 'clients are charged through recurring subscription fees on a pay-as-you-go basis...For SaaS licenses to be sustainable, software vendors would have to take into account not only the costs of hosting and maintaining the software, but also the costs associated with the provision of supplementary services (e.g., backup and security)' | Page 3: 'Cost-based pricing makes sense for SaaS because the remote hosting of software services culminates in significant variable costs for vendors'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Software delivered via cloud with multi-tenant/multi-instance architecture enabling easy access, flexible pricing, lower initial costs, faster implementation, and cost-effective maintenance compared to traditional licensing

Customer Segment: B2B organizations including telecom operators, network operators, financial institutions, government organizations, furniture manufacturers/retailers, and game players; ranging from small-medium businesses to large enterprises with varying IT capabilities
Revenue Streams: Software renting (subscription-based per user per month), traditional perpetual licensing, revenue sharing with partners in value chain
Key Resources: Cloud infrastructure (public cloud, multi-tenant/multi-instance architecture), software applications, technical features for updates and maintenance
Key Activities: Software development, hosting and maintenance, implementation and installation, after-sales support, updates delivery to all customers simultaneously
Key Partnerships: Network operators (for game delivery), content owners (game developers), portals, IT infrastructure providers

Cost Structure: Production costs (traveling costs for installation, implementation, maintenance, after-sales support), operating costs for service and system capacity, data storage and computing power costs
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'by the pure-SaaS model, all the participants in a project gained easy and instant access to the software wherever they were located physically' | Page 3: 'Firm A prefers software renting on the grounds that it brings cost savings by decreasing production costs. These cost savings are related in particular to the traveling costs for installation, implementation, maintenance, and after-sales support' | Page 3-4: 'the final revenue is shared with the partners in the value chain... It is based on revenue sharing between three players, the content owner, a portal, and ourselves' | Page 5: 'The rental model through the public cloud decreased the production costs of case firms... the case firms were able to bring updates that were visible to all their customers immediately'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Standardized ERP, CRM, HRM, payment systems with need-to-have functionality (external accounting, tax reporting, payroll); cloud-based delivery provides cost efficiency, pay-as-you-go mode, great flexibility and scalability, decreased demand for IT skills

Customer Segment: Three categories - micro size business (out-of-box standardized products), small and medium size business with less than 1000 employees (customized through partners), bigger SMB requiring intensive consulting
Channels: Direct sales to micro business; Value-added-Resellers (platinum partners, gold partners, smaller partners/resellers) for small-medium business segment
Relationship: Partners who develop customized products and services; online product training and helpdesk for micro business; close collaboration with partners; user community for value co-creation
Revenue Streams: Transition from upfront perpetual license fees to periodic subscription fees; partners receive up to 50% of initial license fees
Key Resources: In-house product development; standardized products; R&D resources distributed between SaaS and on-premise products
Key Activities: Product development and maintenance of standardized products; transition management from on-premise to cloud; partner support and ecosystem management
Key Partnerships: Value-added-Resellers (platinum, gold, and smaller partners); suppliers include ERP Co IT and Microsoft; BPO partners
Cost Structure: R&D allocation between SaaS and on-premise products; partner compensation for SaaS sales; controlled transition costs
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1, Section 2: 'low/minimal entry costs, pay-as-you-go mode, and great flexibility and scalability' | Page 4, Section 4.2: 'software that supports external accounting, tax reporting, and payroll became the new focus of ERP Co' | Page 5, Section 5.1: 'The customer segments can be further divided into three categories. First, we have micro size business, which out of box standardized products are directly sold to... The second segment is small and medium size business with less than 1000 employees, where ERP Co works closely with their partners' | Page 5: 'up to 50% of the initial ERP Co license fees do go to VAR' | Page 5: 'their major providers include ERP Co IT (a company owned by ERP Co) and Microsoft' | Page 2, Section 2: 'instead of relying on upfront license fee, IT vendors are now collecting periodic subscription fee' | Page 7, Section 5.2.2: 'ERP Co is looking to compensate some of the partners (especially the ones that solely rely on ERP Co) for the initial years for the sales of SaaS products (higher percentages of subscription fees will go to the partners, for instance).'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Pure software product, software-hardware combination, or service; low marginal distribution cost; global scale distribution; network effects; platform/ecosystem offering
Customer Segment: Enterprises or individuals; specialized product or mass market; broad area or niche focus; market leader or complementary offering
Channels: Internet and cloud computing enable service delivery; global scale distribution; low marginal distribution cost
Revenue Streams: Recurring revenue through service component
Key Resources: Developers as strategic asset with high productivity differences; organization structures that let developers write great software; engineering talent; open source components

Key Activities: Product/service management balancing features vs. quality attributes (usability, security, maintainability, reliability, efficiency); software development; operations management; constant investment in software to avoid obsolescence
Key Partnerships: Platform/ecosystem partners that depend on the business; volunteer community for crowdsourcing; outsourcing relationships

Cost Structure: Low marginal distribution cost; licensing costs; operations investment for service delivery; risk of shrunk revenue and profit margins in transitions; investment in tools and hardware for developers
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Will that be a pure software product, such as Microsoft Windows; a software–hardware combination (consider the iPhone); or a service, such as eBay? Having a service component in your offering lets you secure recurring revenue.' | Page 1: 'You can target enterprises or individuals, you can create a specialized product or appeal to the masses, you can cover a broad area or focus on a niche, and you can lead the market or complement an existing offering.' | Page 1: 'The low marginal distribution cost (the cost of adding another user) means that additional sales can often directly translate into pure profit.' | Page 2: 'offering a platform or an ecosystem in which your business can grow together with others that depend on yours' | Page 2: 'given the big productivity differences among developers, your engineers will likely be a strategic asset rather than just a cog in your operations' machinery' | Page 1: 'It might involve painful redundancies and adjustments for shrunk revenue and profit margins.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Four archetypes - Sustainable Software Solutions (software to optimize resource consumption), Sustainable Product-Service Systems (physical products with digital complements for sustainability), Sustainability Intelligence (data analytics for sustainability assessment and decision-making), Digital Sustainable Platforms (multi-sided markets for circular economy)

Customer Segment: Companies seeking ecological sustainability, individuals seeking sustainable consumption, investors, restaurants/supermarkets/hotels, municipalities, complementors in circular economy
Channels: Digital platforms, mobile apps, software platforms, IoT sensors, multi-sided markets
Revenue Streams: Recurring revenue/subscription (14 cases), One-time sales (9), Commission (6), Freemium/Add-on (8), Advertising (1)
Key Resources: Digital technologies (software, data analytics, IoT, blockchain, AI, machine learning), sustainability science knowledge, sensor networks, digital platforms
Key Activities: Data analytics, software optimization, resource optimization, sustainability assessment, marketplace orchestration, value co-creation enablement
Key Partnerships: Complementors, value network partners, suppliers, customers, municipalities, restaurants/supermarkets/hotels
Cost Structure: not detailed in article
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 10, Table 2 - Taxonomy: Shows all BM dimensions including value proposition (digital offering, eco-dimension, differentiation strategy), value creation and delivery (role of IT, sustainability patterns, role in value creation), and revenue model | Page 11, Table 3: Definitions of four archetypes with examples | Page 15, Table 4: Shows ecological value, economic value, and digital value for each archetype

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Two types - Bundled freemium (adds value through premium sales with bundled features, new product/service combinations, interrelated reinforcing characteristics) and Fragmented freemium (creates value with free products then adds value with many fragmented upsell products that can be sold separately, modular customization based on customer interests)
Customer Segment: Free users and paid/premium users; users willing to try free products; users who upgrade based on interests and willingness to pay
Channels: Apple App Store and digital platforms; free app charts; direct digital distribution
Relationship: Network effects to increase user base; conversion from free to paid users; advertising relationships; user retention
Revenue Streams: Premium upgrades from freemium users; subscription revenue from paying subscribers; advertising sponsorship revenue from basic subscribers; separately priced features/services
Key Resources: User base; free product offering; premium features/modules; digital platform infrastructure; data for analytics
Key Activities: Enhancing network effects; converting free users to paid users; increasing user retention; business model innovation; value creation and value capture; modular product development
Key Partnerships: Advertisers (for ad-sponsored revenue); platform providers (Apple App Store)
Cost Structure: not detailed in article

responses_by_article.article_title: Software as a service: Lessons from the video game industry
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: The game itself, new content with updates and DLCs, bug fixes, feedback and communication mechanism between gamers and development teams
Customer Segment: Gamers who play GaaS-based games
Channels: Digital stores such as Origin (main distribution channels), physical stores (still play a part)

Relationship: Developing players' engagement through updates that take gamers' opinions into account, digital personal assistant, FAQ database, developing communities for feedback and building loyalty
Revenue Streams: Microtransactions, advergaming, subscriptions, season passes, loot boxes
Key Resources: Physical (production studios, computer game stores), intellectual (CRM, production software), human (skilled development team), financial (resources to create, design, and distribute)
Key Activities: Efficient software development, effective production (including design and marketing), suitable IT infrastructure (platforms for updates)

Cost Structure: Fixed overhead costs such as development, server maintenance, and personnel (marginal costs of reproducing and distributing services over Internet are minimal)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'They feature a shop where users can buy credits that provide them with access to additional in-app features compared to non-paying users, such as extra resources for constructing cities or armies more quickly (gaming), or the ability to send messages to other users (dating)' | Page 1: 'a large share of overall revenue derives from a small portion of the user base' | Page 4: 'the top 1% of users contribute up to 84.6% (data set 1), 60.5% (data 2), and 53.6% (data set 3) of total revenue' | Page 3: 'For digital businesses, fixed overhead costs such as development, server maintenance, and personnel are more relevant than the marginal costs of reproducing and distributing services over the Internet'

responses_by_article.article_title: Understanding the influence of absorptive capacity and ambidexterity on the process of business model change – the case of on-premise and cloud-computing software
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: On-demand access to ERP functionalities through internet without need for own IT infrastructure, shifting from capital to operational expenditures, scalable and rapidly implementable services, integrated on-premise and on-demand solutions

Customer Segment: Initially low-end customers and SMEs over-served by existing ERP, then lines of business with standardised processes, later larger enterprises demanding private/hybrid cloud solutions
Channels: Internet as direct distribution channel, downloadable trial versions, reduced role of indirect distribution networks and implementation partners
Revenue Streams: Pay-per-use pricing replacing one-time license fees and annual maintenance contracts, continuous but less predictable cash flows
Key Resources: Web technologies (Ajax, HTML5), capacity management capabilities, multi-tenant architecture, agile software development competencies
Key Activities: Continuous software development and updates (shorter release cycles), managing entire software lifecycle including deployment and maintenance, capacity management
Key Partnerships: Software partners providing extensions and add-ons, implementation partners (diminished role), hosting partners, application-programming interfaces for ecosystem

Cost Structure: Upfront investments for software development and SaaS infrastructure setup, permanent overhead costs for keeping service infrastructure ready, economies of scale crucial for profitability
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 17-20: Detailed descriptions of business model components changes including 'Value proposition' section stating 'customer firms are exempted from much of the cost and effort of operating and financing their own IT infrastructure', 'Customer interface' describing target segments, 'Infrastructure management' detailing competencies needed, 'Financial aspects' explaining 'pay-per-use pricing method' and cost structures

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: On-demand access to ERP/CRM/HRM systems over Internet, low/minimal entry costs, flexibility and scalability, eliminates need for upfront capital investment and own IT infrastructure
Customer Segment: Three segments - micro businesses (standardized out-of-box products), small-medium businesses with <1000 employees (tailored systems through VAR), bigger SMBs (intensive consulting)
Channels: Direct sales to micro businesses, VAR/partner network (platinum, gold, smaller partners) for small-medium segment, online helpdesk and training
Relationship: From product-based to service-based relationship, shift to value co-creation with customers through user communities, continuous support vs one-time sale
Revenue Streams: Shift from upfront perpetual license fees to periodic subscription fees (pay-as-you-go), continuous cash flow but less predictable, 50% of initial license fees go to VAR
Key Resources: Standardized products developed in-house, SaaS platform, partner network, technical and human resources
Key Activities: In-house product development, partner relationship management, customer support and training, continuous product maintenance and updates

Key Partnerships: VAR partners (platinum exclusively with ERP Co, gold mainly with ERP Co, smaller local/micro market partners), suppliers (ERP Co IT, Microsoft), complementary relationships requiring careful ecosystem management
Cost Structure: R&D resources allocation (initially 80/20 SaaS/on-premise, later 50/50 hybrid), acquisition costs, partner compensation, continuous maintenance and support costs
responses_by_article.source_citation: Pages 4-7 provide extensive details about all business model components including customer segments, partner model, revenue streams, transition strategy, and ecosystem relationships

responses_by_article.article_title: Business models and opportunity creation: How IT entrepreneurs create and develop business models under uncertainty
responses_by_article.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Cloud gaming platform enabling games to run on servers and stream to end-user devices, avoiding illegal copying and second-hand markets, providing more durable market for games with flexible revenue models, eliminating need for powerful client hardware
Customer Segment: Evolution from mobile game players (3G users) to PC players and IPTV users, finally to cloud console players and IPTV players with broadband connections
Channels: Telecommunication operators (3G, IPTV), portals for PC users, network operators, direct through cloud console device
Key Resources: Gaming platform technology, MPEG streaming, game servers, SDK for game developers, licensed game content, broadband infrastructure
Key Activities: Porting licensed games to platform (initially), providing SDK and quality assurance (later), platform operation and maintenance, content licensing negotiations

Key Partnerships: Game publishers (content providers), telecom/IPTV operators (distribution), video-on-demand service providers, set-top box manufacturers, middleware software providers, portals, server manufacturers

Revenue Streams: Revenue sharing model among partners (portals/IPTV operators charge end-users, divide income between partners including G-cluster and game licensors), flexible models including game rental
Cost Structure: R&D activities in Finland, platform development and maintenance, game porting costs (reduced after SDK introduction), server infrastructure
responses_by_article.source_citation: Pages 10-17 with Figures 1-4 showing complete business model evolution including all components: product/service (gaming platform), value network (partners and customers), value delivery (distribution channels), and revenue model (revenue sharing)
